[[User:Khirad|Khirad]][[User talk:Khirad|talk]] 03:09, 4 January 2006 (UTC) == neutrality/accuracy == The opening of this article is incredibly misleading. Religious cosmologies, while they may be accepted by religious individuals, are in no way "epistemologically valid." The claim that science rests on religious foundations is truly a tired, old, and frankly ridiculous argument. One of the greatest virtues of science is that it allows us to ''overcome'' our religious mythologies by evaluating claims in terms of empirically verifiable facts. If its basis were religious in nature, it would have no greater claim to objectivity than religious cosmologies. This is not the case. Science relies on hard facts, not mythological tradition. The claim that religious cosmologies constitute valid epistemology is not simply biased, it is flat-out false.
